topic.title: Using BTSync, One Hub etc. for data storage
topic.body:
Hi all. Betatester here, renamed betatester2 after I lost my first ZeroID. I had started earlier a thread called « ZerHello VS Maelstrom etc.”, it’s here: http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:2_1MS7WkWAZUSohgV5uUF2Ze3kdbifi4J82L/ZeroHello+vs+Maelstrom+etc

In this thread I asked a question “unless I missed something with ZeroHello, a website has to be "followed" by a peer to stay available, there is no way to provide storage to the ZeroHello peer so that random data can be saved”.

This new thread is a spin off to focus on that particular topic: data storage. Since ZeroNet is based on the Bit Torrent protocol to decentralize the data, essentially the websites shall we say for now, my question is: Could we use Bit Torrent Sync with or without its One Hub professional capability to increase/guarantee website retention? I elaborate: If a ZeroNet website is launched, then it will rely on ZeroNet peers to subscribe to this website in order to guarantee access and provide download speed. But there is only so many websites a peer is going to be able/willing to have on his ZeroNet homepage. Bookmarking a ZeroNet website isn’t going to allow for local data storage. That’s limiting website owners’ willingness to adopt ZeroNet as a platform because it takes time to build a website. Now, if the business owner is using Bit Torrent Sync to have its websites’ torrent files made available by peers willing to share a read-only folder, then there is a possibility to have the torrent files available 24/7, with redundancy and download speed increasing according to the swarm’s size. As I already said in previous posts, I’m not a programmer, but I like ZeroNet, I think it’s one of the most interesting project out there with MadeSafe and Storj, so I’d like to see my company’s websites replicated into ZeroNet, but I need to have a better understanding of this standard, from a user’s standpoint not a programmer’s.

topic.title: Bitmessage : Windows .exe or Python source code ?
topic.body:
Hi all,

I have a question about Bitmessage. There are two versions of this software, one for Windows and one written in Python (source code, original version from Github).

- Windows: https://www.bitmessage.org/wiki/Main_Page
- Python: https://github.com/Bitmessage/PyBitmessage 

After having used the Python one for some time I thought I should use the Windows version since I’m running Windows, it’s a standalone .exe that launches with Windows so it’s pretty simple and practical. However my antivirus Bit Defender has detected it as a threat and removed it. I tested this .exe on VirusTotal and one antivirus out of 55 said it had detected a “Trojan.Win32.Agent.3514855[h]”. So I re-downloaded the Python version and VirusTotal didn’t find any malicious line in it. Now I don’t know if the Windows .exe was just a false positive or if there is a real danger in running this software.
It seems there is a way to use a bitmessage through a web browser, but I couldn’t receive any message using this: https://bitmsg.me

If someone has some experience with Bitmessage, thanks for sharing.

topic.title: Notifications for comments and updates
topic.body: It's nice to be able to post comments on Zeronet websites and forums and blogs, but it's impossible to have a real social activity if we don't get notifications when someone is answering to a thread or a comment or updating a page. Since we have to be logged in using our ZeroID to post comments, it would be nice to us Zeromail to get notifications about all these social media activities.

"Hello, I have installed Malestrom about 2 weeks ago. I had Windows Defender detecting several malwares and trojan. This morning Bit Defender found a plethora of threats coming from Maelstrom, it desinfected the .exe and .lnk and more than 30 files in the subfolders C:\users\myaccount\appdata\local\maelstrom\user data and then: - extension state - local extension state - sync app settings - history provider cache - evwhitelist - managed extension settings - file system - default\bookmarks I can send the zip of this \user data folder to the dev team. So, is Maelstrom considered a virus or is it an entry door to virus and trojan as soon as we start using it? Thanks,"

OK, but are there any ways we can have some sort of connections with torrent servers, that way the ZeroNet webmaster can place its website on ZeroNet and on a few torrent servers to provide for the initial seeding. Alternatively we'll need some ZeroNet peers connected with fiber to the internet and willing to seed the new websites for a few weeks. In any case we'll always have the problem of popularity, which is the same problem there is in Freenet, only popular websites get a chance to stay available. On Freenet freesites have to be reloaded to the data storage regularly.

But then it defeats the purpose of having TOR bundled with Zeronet. If I want to send all the traffic using Zeronet's instance of TOR by 127.0.0.1:49050 This is a setting I do in the browser or in Windows connexion settings? I've tried both, still not working. Now I even get a TOR waiting status in Zeronet, so it's not exactly getting better. I'm using TOR browser for other tasks so I'm not interested in screwing up my working TOR connexion with Zeronet.

> [iamdeath](#comment_28_1DcE9QfZbfLZhXxgtQ8Ui3oMZvs9NVjqZB): It calls http://l2.io/ip.js?var=myip, which is just an external site that responds with your IP address. So all it's doing is accessing an external site.

I've just tried this link. I have Port closed and Tor always. And again it's showing my real IP. So if I understand it right: Zeronet's TOR is to hide IP from other TOR users. But when you go to the clearnet, it's business as usual. That's fine by me if it means I can help others seed their Zerosites without risking to be caught because of their content. The problem is that Zeronet's TOR sometimes doesn't connect, meaning that while it's updating the Zerosites, it's showing my real IP, so much for reliability. I think it's safer to not start Zeronet at system start up, start a VPN first and then start Zeronet, even with its own TOR. Sure it will make it slow, but it reduces the risk to get involved because of some innapropriate content that ends up in the swarm. Or proxy the entire browser, but then you have to trust the proxy for anonymity because it's going to be the same proxy address all the time.
